comment._content: This is the only turntable at Dundalk on the old OSI map. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,704179,806395,7,9 It's all desolate now on Google Maps The original shaded lettering "17?" is more ornate than the new lettering "CIE".

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Hi Carol/guys. If that is indeed #171 (and beachcomber's tag seems to highlight that it probably is), then it's likely this engine: www.steamtrainsireland.com/locomotives/loco171.htm (Looks like it appeared in Michael Collins film. Alongside Julia Robert's dopey accent. Looks like the RPSI guys are chasing funding to have it restored: www.steamtrainsireland.com/171/ The engine that is. Not Ms Roberts clunky accent....)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Thanks [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00]! So this is the Slieve Gullion then, which had a very special outing yesterday? We thought we'd found it before, but it was actually another 171...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Any similarity is purely coincidental -

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I wondered about that. Looking at the photos of the fundraising outing (below) it looks like that engine wasn't involved itself. It was a 171 mile journey FOR the engine. But a modern diesel did it. (Might be good to connect with those lads. Am sure they'd be a mine of info on any rolling-stock photos...) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gbrailphotos/sets/72157629878451225/]

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Very nice portrait of 171. In the background is the GNR's 'general stores' building, which is a little run down these days. A lot of CIE's steam locos were scrapped in the Dundalk works and this may explain the number of engine wheels dumped in the background.
